title: Matsunoo Taisha
text:
, formerly , is a <a href="Shinto%20shrine">Shinto shrine</a> located at the far western end of <a href="Shij%C5%8D%20Street">Shijō Street</a>, approximately 1.3 kilometers south of the <a href="Arashiyama">Arashiyama</a> district of <a href="Kyoto">Kyoto</a>. It is home to a <a href="Spring%20%28hydrosphere%29">spring</a> at the base of the mountain, Arashiyama, that is believed to be blessed.
It is said that during the move of the capital from <a href="Nara%2C%20Nara">Nara</a> to Kyoto, a noble saw a turtle bathing under the spring's waterfall and created a shrine there. It is one of the oldest shrines in the Kyoto area, its founding extending back to 700 CE. The restorative properties of the spring bring many local <a href="sake">sake</a> and <a href="miso">miso</a> companies to the shrine for prayers that their product will be blessed.
The shrine also serves a "kinpaku miki" (gold leaf filled blessed sake) during "<a href="hatsum%C5%8Dde">hatsumōde</a>".
History.
The shrine became the object of Imperial patronage during the early <a href="Heian%20period">Heian period</a>. In 965, <a href="Emperor%20Murakami">Emperor Murakami</a> ordered that Imperial messengers were sent to report important events to the guardian "<a href="kami">kami</a>" of Japan. These "heihaku" were initially presented to 16 shrines including the Matsunoo Shrine.
From 1871 through 1946, Matsunoo-taisha was officially designated one of the , meaning that it stood in the first rank of government supported shrines.
